column4: It seems an odd question, but is it possible to run a program by a user which hasn't a shell?
yes, in fact its preferable for many programs to run as a user whos shell is set to /bin/false
yes or more precisly depends on the program.  Some have command switches to run as a user
Tor have a config switch that says "drop root privileges and use this user instead". But I am actually not very comfortable believing in that.
its not very difficult to implement in a program, it it says it will run as a user, and ps shows it running as that user, well it is doing what it was set to do
Well. I think that you're right. But don't you fell very uncomfortable running something as root?

me personally no, but then again the stuff I run as root I know about, can read the source code and understand what it does.  I do with with mythtv so I can set proity threads, then again my myth frontends are more appliances then systems
Hum. Well, for now I will try the jrib solution until I get around the idea.
implitly root is not evil, its just dangerous.  Especially in the hands of a semi-knowledgeable user.  Or quite literally "a little bit of knowledge is a dangerous thing"
The all concept of running a process with super privileges just make me fell funny.
I dont think it was jribs idea as much as he gave you the command to run a program as a different user.  I would call it jrib was correct.
some things HAVE to run as root, thigns that access hardware directly (xorg being most notable).  But not all things need root.
I think I didn't quite understand what you meant about jrib "idea".
ok, but pay attention to what jrib tells you, he is knowledgeable
I know, I know. (although there are many people that do not like the idea of xorg been run as a privileged process)
like I said, root isnt dangerous any more then a rifle is.  It is how it is used (I would say misused) that is.
I personally would say that a rifle is *always* dangerous. But let not visit that place.
